description.narrative:
Projektförslaget bygger på en pågående insats i Mali 2013-2015 ’Strengthening Civil Society contributions to peace, security and development’. Genom denna insats utvecklades en strategisk vision för det civila samhällets deltagande i fred- och försoningsprocessen för nationell samhörighet genom en stor konferens i september 2015 med ett brett deltagande från civila samhället, maliska ministerier, academia och internationella partners.
Syftet med det nya projektet är att stärka det civila samhällets organisationer (CSOs) för att på så vis bidra till fred och säkerhet och därmed utveckling. Genom att öka CSOs möjligheter att förstå sig på och bevaka människors uppfattning om trygghet och säkerhet i sin omgivning och förmedla detta till beslutsfattare i landet, förutser man ett bredare inflytande av det civila samhället på Malis policyramverk och en mer inkluderande fredsprocess. Detta ska uppnås genom att bland annat utbilda ca 100 representanter från det civila samhället runt om i landet för bättre bevakning och analys och genom att diskutera trygghet och säkerhetsfrågor via två stora konferenser. Ökad allmän kunskap om befolkningens uppfattning vad gäller trygghet och säkerhetsfrågor vill man ska stärkas genom en bred media kampanj och genom att försöka påverka beslutsfattare inom både lokala och nationella nätverk. Det övergripande målet sammanfattas sålunda: ’To improve post-conflict national and local policies to address the safety and security challenges for the population, through increased integration of civil society perspectives on these challenges’
Efter statskuppen i mars 2012 har Mali genomlevt ett instabilt säkerhetsläge. För att uppnå fattigdomsminskning, vilket är den viktigaste prioriteringen för Malis regering och därmed det övergripande målet för det svenska utvecklingssamarbetet med Mali, måste säkerhetssituationen stabiliseras. I maj och juni i år skrev de stridande parterna under ett Fredsavtal. För att implementerandet av fredsavtalet ska bli så legitimt som möjligt, är det viktigt att även inkludera det civila samhället. Projektet stödjer detta genom att utbilda CSOs från de olika regionerna i landet inom kartläggningsmetoder, analys och rapportering för att på så vis stärka det civila samhällets engagemang då beslut som påverkar fredsprocessen ska fattas.
Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) är ett Stockholmsbaserat, självständigt institut som etablerades 1966 och som även har kontor i Beijing och Washington. SIPRI arbetar med forskning inom konflikt, vapen, vapenkontroll och nedrustning. Organisationen tillhandahåller data, analyser och rekommendationer till beslutsfattare, forskare och media. Fördelen med att välja SIPRI som partner för denna insats är att SIPRI redan har erfarenhet av samarbete med det civila samhället i Mali. Innan det Sidastödda projektet 2013-2015 genomförde SIPRI ett tre-årigt projekt som bl.a. involverade fem länder söder om Sahara, däribland Mali och dess civila samhälle. Projektet, som hette ’Africa, Security and Governance’, fokuserade på betydelsen av det civila samhället för kontraterrorism. Sida har även sedan tidigare positiv erfarenhet av att arbeta med SIPRI genom projektet ’Conflict Sensitive Logistics and Ethical Transporation Clearinghouse’ där det övergripande målet var att få målgrupperna för projektet att minska sin användning av företag som sysslar med vapenhandel. Sida noterade att insatsen var framgångsrik både gällande resultat fastställda i avtalet samt rapportering till Sida vid avtalad tidpunkt.
SIPRI har även erfarenhet av arbete med La Coalition Nationale de la Société Civile pour la Paix et la Lutte contre la Prolifération des Armes Légères (CONASCIPAL) som är en paraplyorganisation för cirka 20 av civila samhällets organisationer i Mali. CONASCIPAL har sedan det startades 1998 organiserat en mängd konferenser och möten kring fred, säkerhet och lätta vapen.
Projektet bygger på SIPRIs analytiska förmåga, opartiska forskning, gedigna metodologi och empiriska tillvägagångssätt tillsammans med lokala partnern CONASCIPALs breda och mångfasetterade nätverk som utökades ytterligare under det pågående projektet. SIPRI besitter således relevant kompetens och erfarenhet som ger en klar fördel inför det föreslagna projektet. Mot denna bakgrund bedöms SIPRI vara en trovärdig samarbetspartner för Sida i befrämjandet av fred och säkerhet i Mali och insatsen bedöms som relevant.

The SIPRI project proposal follows an on-going intervention in Mali, namely the 2013-2015 ’Strengthening Civil Society contributions to peace, security and development’. Through this intervention, a strategic vision for civil society’s participation in the peace- and reconciliation process for national unity was drafted through a large conference in September 2015 with a broad participation from civil society from across the country, the Malian ministries and international partners. The project at hand aims at enhancing civil society contributions to peace and security and thus development. By increasing civil society’s possibilities to understand and monitor people’s perception about safety and security challenges and by communicating this to decision-makers in the country, civil society will be able to contribute to and have broader influence on policies while the peace process will be more inclusive. This will be achieved by among others training approximately 100 representatives from civil society around the country in monitoring and analysis and by discussing safety and security issues through two big seminars. General awareness around the population's perception regarding safety and security issues will increase through broad media campaigns and by trying to influence decision-makers through both local and national networks. The main goal is thus summarized as follows: ‘To improve post-conflict national and local policies to address the safety and security challenges for the population, through increased integration of civil society perspectives on these challenges’.After the coup in March 2012, Mali has experienced a vulnerable security situation. In order to achieve poverty reduction, which is the most important priority for the Malian government and thus the overarching goal for Swedish cooperation with Mali, the security situation needs to improve. In May and June this year, the conflicting parties signed a Peace Accord. In order to ensure a legitimate implementation of the Accord, it is important to also include civil society. SIPRI’s project aims at supporting this by training CSOs from the various regions in the country in mapping, analysis and reporting in order to strengthen civil society participation when decisions involving the peace process are to be taken. The advantage in selecting SIPRI as a partner for this contribution is that SIPRI already has experience in working with civil society in Mali. Prior to the Sida funded project 2013-2015, SIPRI conducted a three-year project that among others involved five sub-Saharan countries, among them Mali and its civil society. The project, entitled ‘Africa, Security and Governance’, focused on civil society’s role in counter terrorism. Sida also has positive experience from working with SIPRI through the project ‘Conflict Sensitive Logistics and Ethical Transportation Clearinghouse’ where the overarching goal was to encourage the target groups in the project to decrease the use of companies involved in the trading in weapons. Sida noted that the intervention was successful both in terms of predetermined results in the agreement as well as in the timely reporting to Sida. SIPRI also has experience from working with La Coalition Nationale de la Société Civile pour la Paix et la Lutte contre la Prolifération des Armes Légères (CONASCIPAL), a non-governmental umbrella organisation with around 20 CSOs in Mali. CONASCIPAL has, since it was established in 1998, organized a number of workshops and seminars around peace, security and light weapons. The project builds on SIPRIs analytical competencies and strong reputation of unbiased research, solid methodologies and empirical approach and the local partner CONASCIPAL’s broad and diverse networks and contacts that were further expanded during the on-going project.
To improve post-conflict national and local policies to address the safety and security challenges for the population, through increased integration of civil society perspectives on these challenges.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.b - Promote and enforce non-discriminatory laws and policies for sustainable development.
16.b - Verka för och genomdriva icke-diskriminerande lagstiftning och politik för en hållbar utveckling.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative: The most important changes that the program has led to are the following: The Project collaborated with civil society actors in 36 Malian municipalities across the country’s ten regions to monitor and document the security situation at grass-root level, its perceived causes and suggestions for policy action. Furthermore, it strengthened the capacity of Malian civil society actors to enable them to participate more in peacebuilding activities, with the overall goal to increase and strengthen their contributions to peace, security and development. It also completed a mapping analysis of civil society perspectives on the conflict in the North. 13 qualitative studies were conducted on different themes including among other the population’s perception on security, role of external actors in local politics and United Nations Security Council’s Resolution 1325. With regard to this latter, 36 women were trained to conduct focus groups and to collect data. In addition, the 1325 component of the Project culminated in a press conference (June 27, 2019), a dedicated radio show broadcasted on Studio Tamani (July 28, 2019) and the publication of a 21-page Insight Report, Main dans la main: Insecurity and Gender in Mali (December 2019). In the course of the Project, three Knowledge Exchange Workshops took place. This helped empower the women as representatives of their communities and highlighted the centrality of women’s views and perspective on the conflict in Mali. A WhatsApp group was created by SIPRI and gathering both CONASCIPAL and all the facilitators of the Project. This was used as a digital equivalent of a platform for national dialogue around local and national issues of peace and security. It allowed regular exchanges and discussions on the Project, and real-time information sharing about the security, political and economic situation in the 10 regions. While the project formally ended September 30, 2019, the WhatsApp group is still partially active and regularly used by the Project partners to share information about Mali or the situation in their respective localities. However, with no specific solicitation by the Project’s teams, the Group is less and less active. The Project relied on a network of 36 Monitoring Groups for Peace and Security (MGPS) and 13 facilitators spread across all ten regions of Mali to collect, through the distribution of three (3) thematic questionnaires, the perceptions of civil society on human security and economic and social development issues across the country. The Mid-Term Evaluation identified the MGPS Network as one of the major strengths of the Project. Indeed, the MGPS contributed in a significant manner to social cohesion in their respective communities and between different groups. The 56-page Livre Blanc de la société civile pour la paix et la sécurité au Mali is the final and culminating product of the Project. Steered by a White Book Commission and coordinated and facilitated by two scientific coordinators, the White Book translates the Project’s findings into practical, solutions-oriented policy recommendations to curb the spread of insecurity and violence in Mali. In July 2019, the 8-page English summary – Civil Society White Book on Peace and Security in Mali (2019) – was published. SIPRI’s expertise on Mali was regularly solicited by major international media, to provide a contextualized understanding of specific events (postponing’s of the elections, attacks by armed groups, international conference, ministerial tours, etc.). From 2017 onwards, SIPRI’s media presence increased significantly, with interviews and quotes in major Malian and international outlets, such as Le Monde, Al Jazeera, Le J DD, L'Espresso, RFI, Mikado FM, Mediapart, or the Journal du Mali. The Malian Government expressed its need for more information to the EU Delegation in Mali, who in turn directly asked SIPRI to develop a specific project to monitor the needs of populations in the two central regions of Mali and to assess the impact of EU interventions on communities’ daily life. This new 3-year Project started in August 2018 and built on the methodology that was developed in the Sida-funded Project. The SIPRI Sahel/West Africa Programme and the Swedish MFA launched a quarterly Sahel Forum that brings together SIPRI, Swedish Government officials working on the Sahel from across different Governmental organisations and research institutes (Forum for Africa studies, Nordiska Afrikainstitutet) to discuss the Project’s research findings and other participants’ work in the Sahel region. The Project results prompted discussions that help improve coordination among those working on Mali and the Sahel in Sweden. The SIPRI team also organized a Sahel Forum at the SIPRI office on June 4, 2018 and participated in the Forum at the Swedish MFA on November 23, 2018. In addition, the team regularly met with colleagues from the University of Uppsala - also via SIPRI’s senior associate Pr Sten Hagberg - to share expertise and discuss peace and security challenges, development concerns and political processes in Mali and the Sahel.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
